head.title: Gold Investors Scramble to Sell As Strong New Year Rally Dims

hedline.hl1: Gold Investors Scramble to Sell As Strong New Year Rally Dims

block.p: Gold prices fell yesterday to their lowest levels in two months as a New Year's rally that had carried the market to six-year highs faded, and disappointed investors scrambled to sell.
"People were getting impatient, and the price of gold wasn't going anywhere," said Greg Drury, director of precious metals at Mitsui & Company in the United States.
Gold prices fell yesterday to their lowest levels in two months as a New Year's rally that had carried the market to six-year highs faded, and disappointed investors scrambled to sell.
"People were getting impatient, and the price of gold wasn't going anywhere," said Greg Drury, director of precious metals at Mitsui & Company in the United States.

At the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, gold for April delivery tumbled $5, to $395.20 an ounce, the lowest since Jan. 3 and off nearly $25 from the six-year high of $419.60 reached on Feb. 2.
With energy and grain prices also falling, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 17 commodities dropped 0.85, to 243.61.
Other precious metals prices also fell. May silver lost 12.3 cents, to $5.417 an ounce, and April platinum dropped $4.80, to $408 an ounce.
Dinsa Mehta, managing director at Chase Manhattan, said the gold market seemed overbought recently, but traders and analysts said there was no fresh news behind the selloff.

Bullish investors had focused on expectations that gold mine output would remain stagnant while buying in the fast-growing Asian economies would continue rising. But the continuing strength in the stock market deflated expectations that investors would move into hard assets like gold.
Crude oil prices fell further, casting doubt on whether the energy sector would mount a late winter rally.
April crude lost 24 cents, to $19.20 a barrel, and April gasoline declined 1.02 cents, to 58.73 cents a gallon at the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Grain prices fell, hurt partly by moves by two large poultry producers to reduce output, partly because of the high cost of chicken feed made from corn and soybeans.

The approach of the South American soybean harvest also weighed on prices, with March soybeans falling 8 cents, to $7.2025 a bushel at the Chicago Board of Trade. March corn fell 4 cents, to $3.8925 a bushel, and March wheat declined 3 cents, to $5.1225 a bushel.
